PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

(Debate on the Address)
(Fourth Allotted Day)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [13th January, 1994],

    'That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:-

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the Second Session of this Parliament.".' - [Mr Loh Meng See].

    Question again proposed.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Thank you, Mr Speaker, for allowing me to join in the debate.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in many developed countries, social values are found to be in transition. In many of these places, values are also in conflict. Problems have arisen in many of these places because of value conflicts related to interpersonal problems, social responsibility, marital and other related problems. These have plagued

Column: 282

many of these developed countries. We should deal with some of these intangibles because these are very important issues in the context of Singapore and we must address these issues so that we will not, in the longer term, be caught with these problems.

    Sir, we must ensure that the family continues to be a viable institution to imbue social and cultural values to our young. In doing so, it will help to build a cultural ballast that will enable our young to choose appropriate social and cultural values and discard those that are negative and decadent. This will prevent the development of social problems such as drug abuse, delinquency, marital and extra-marital problems, personal and moral degradations. In short, good social and cultural values will contribute to healthy growth and development of children and hence strengthen the foundation of our society. I am sure you will agree with me, Sir, that this is very important.

    One crucial factor which determines whether our young adults will become responsible parents is the type of social and cultural values they are exposed to. The young adults' capacity to handle crises will be determined, to a considerable extent, by the social and cultural values preferred by his family and community. Therefore, social and cultural values transmitted by various significant institutions such as the school, cultural groups, media and the family should blend together harmoniously and contradictions can be prevented.

    I see that there are increasing contradictions arising in our context. Contradictions between the media, the family and the school institutions, I feel, have to be minimised so that the transmission of these social and cultural values could, to some extent, be transmitted more systematically and more harmoniously.

    Sir, with increasing pressure to relax censorship of printed and visual information, there is a danger that contradictions in value transmission between these institutions will increase and it is increasingly so with the introduction of less

Column: 283

censorship and other related policy changes in this direction. I feel that we should guard against the problems that will arise as a result of this relaxation. It is therefore important that our Government should send appropriate signals and take calculated action to deal with the media that promotes permissiveness and erodes our moral fibre. Government should, in the first place, be clear about what are the socially desirable materials to be allowed. If we do not take care of this issue, in the longer term, this will flood our society and therefore will create disconcerting values amongst the very young.

    The social health of any progressive society varies directly with human values of its people and their capacity to find social antigens to counter decadent values which erode social responsibilities of its people.

    A number of significant social factors will have impact and influence on the dynamics of the family and family life. Some of these social factors have already been identified by my colleagues yesterday and I shall not dwell on them in detail. But some of these factors such as declining birth rate or fertility, increasing participation of women in the labour force, continuing breakdown in the extended family composition, delaying marriages, and increasing number of persons in singlehood and divorces, have to some extent created impact and changes in the family. All these aforementioned social factors have important bearing on the current and future programmes for the families. Consequently, it will have implications for the provision of services in dealing with families and I think there is an urgent need to look at how we can strengthen the foundation of the family further.

    Sir, the other issue directly related to this is the time that the commuters are spending outside their home. More commuters of public transport now feel that their travelling and waiting time has increased because of too many points of transfer. Time with the family is also lessened. Commuters are beginning to

Column: 284

become frustrated because they feel that they have taken too many unnecessary rides, and sometimes taken for a ride too! There is a need to review whether the present bus company monopoly should be maintained. A few more bus companies should be allowed to operate so that more competition could be introduced. I do not see there is a need to have just SBS and TIBS to operate the bus services. In many housing estates, there are Transit Link and internal bus shuttle services. Perhaps there could be an introduction of other companies to compete in the transport service. By this, we will be able to increase the quality of the service and also allow consumers a better choice of the transportation system.

    Sir, I cannot but agree more with our President that we need good people in both public and private institutions. It is the kind of people we have who make the institutions. Therefore, it is important that our Governmental institutions, be it educational, social, political or economic, continue to have people who show genuineness, provide respectability, demonstrate enthusiasm, have empathy, pay attention, carry responsibility, and have humility. In having these qualities, institutions become alive and they do not deteriorate to facelessness. This is a danger among many bureaucracies and unless we can humanise these bureaucracies it will not be able to respond more effectively to the needs of the consumers.

    In this connection, I must alert the Government that there is serious disquiet amongst civil servants over the revised medical benefits scheme. Despite the explanation given, I doubt very much that the civil servants have understood what the scheme is all about. There is a need to explain more clearly what the scheme is all about and what impact this will have on the civil servants themselves. They feel short-changed and this disappointment needs to be redressed so that the people who form the foundation to our Governmental institutions are not demoralised. From my own assessment, talking to some of them, they seem to be quite demoralised at this juncture.

Column: 285



    Sir, we must also ensure that Singapore does not become an individualistic society. If this happens, then Singaporeans can become self-centred and preoccupied with their own interest. People will be less willing to give mutual support to others. This will be bad for Singapore. I am sure you will agree with me, Sir, that we will have to support others who are in need and who are less better off than us. We must continue to encourage Singaporeans to be socially responsible and to extend mutual assistance to others less better off. In this way, we can build a more cohesive society.

    On the broader front, it is necessary for our society to actively promote value education as early as possible before a child begins school. Such an emphasis in our educational curriculum can facilitate helping behaviour. Value education by parents and the schools can encourage good citizenship. In the longer term, it can help to prevent people from becoming more self-centred and uncaring. More people with high social DNA or high social concern should be attracted. These people with an acumen for the promotion of public good will strengthen our social institutions for the discharge of various social obligations.

    Sir, with continued renewal of leadership, it is crucial to the further viability and survival of our various institutions. It is therefore essential to have an institutional philosophy of the need to encourage younger professionals and concerned citizens to be inducted into the leadership of the various organisations. In doing so, we will remain relevant and respond to the changing social needs and problems in our community. In this connection, I hope that younger Singaporeans can learn to be humble and seize various opportunities to achieve their best human potential. As for those of us who are in our adulthood and middle age, we must strive to be effective parents and, where possible, support others who are less better off than us. For those who are greying, like myself, it is important that we brace ourselves to deal with the question of retirement and find re-engagement in

Column: 286

other meaningful activities. I am sure when you grey, you will have to participate in meaningful activities.

    One significant social phenomenon of the near future is the greying of our housing estates. In older housing estates, the aging process has become very transparent. There is an increasing number of older senior citizens living in these housing estates and it is urgent that community groups and organisations, with the support of Government, begin to plan the establishment of more community-based programmes such as day care, meal programmes, home-help service and domiciliary nursing care and other crisis response service to meet their needs. In taking a proactive approach to initiate a network of services in older housing estates, we will be able to provide support for families with vulnerable aged and prevent disruptions to the social and economic lives of these families. I am sure you will agree with me, Sir, that in the older estates, like yours, and some of my colleagues, there is an urgent need to review how the environment of these estates can be made more user-friendly for the older people. If we do not take action to deal with this problem, we will land up with serious problems of inaccessibility for the old in these housing estates.

    One major concern facing the elderly would be the maintenance of good health. It is therefore important to promote healthy living. Otherwise, ill-health at old age can become burdensome and a misery. The prolongation of life as a result of improved medical technology would raise various moral and philosophical issues about the sustenance of life and dying. Our elderly will have to be better prepared to deal with this life reality and dilemma and by encouraging them to draw up perhaps a living will and to also prepare them to deal with this whole question of death and dying. These are the realities of life and I think, in due course, the community and the families, particularly the families having aged parents, will have to deal with this dilemma.

Column: 287



    Sir, our community must also take steps to encourage our elderly to be better prepared to cope with their retirement. The more positive efforts the elderly take in maintaining healthy lifestyles, the less dependent will they be in need for care and attention. We must therefore encourage more of our elderly to be involved in self-help groups in our neighbourhoods. Through these self-help groups and mutual support groups, the elderly with different needs and problems could be assisted. The strong therefore can help the less strong.

    In conclusion, I would like to say that each of us must have renewed faith in what we do. We should continue to spread our wings to find new heights to scale. For this to happen, we must not count on a few, but to count on all who can help to build a better community.

     Mr Robert Chua Teck Chew (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to speak on Mr Loh Meng See's motion to thank the President for his Address at the Opening of this Session of Parliament.

    The President covered a wide range of matters affecting the future of Singaporeans. I wish to share my views on some of them. The business community welcomes the Government's commitment to promote a regional outlook among Singaporeans, and remove obstacles that hinder our entrepreneurs and companies from going offshore. Our relatively small population living on a tiny island with no natural resources must build its future by linking with the larger and resource rich countries of the Asia-Pacific region. We need to tap their resources and participate in their economic growth by increasing our trade and investment linkages with them.

    The political and economic climate is conducive for us to regionalise. In the last few years, our businessmen and companies have been welcomed with open arms to trade with and invest in the countries in this region. Our businessmen have been inundated with countless invitations to visit and invest in those

Column: 288

countries. And almost everyday, there is a delegation of officials and businessmen from a regional country knocking on the door of the Singapore Manufacturers Association (SMA) and asking the SMA to help them organise trade and investment missions and seminars to promote investments in their country or state.

    Just last week, the SMA helped the Malaysian Industrial Development Authority to organise a seminar on "Business Opportunities in Malaysia", led by the Malaysian Minister for International Trade and Industry, Dato Seri Rafidah Aziz, and 1,500 businessmen attended the seminar. The large turn-up clearly demonstrated Singapore companies' interest in regionalisation.

    Malaysian investment figures revealed that Singapore ranked number one going by the country with the largest number of manufacturing projects in operation in Malaysia. Singapore moved up from 9th position in 1992 to fourth position in 1993 in the country ranking based on the annual value of investments in Malaysia's manufacturing sector, overtaking several European countries and Indonesia. Such events show that Singapore is on the right track in its moves to regionalise our economy.

    We should do everything possible to help our companies, especially the small and medium-sized local enterprises, find new business opportunities in the regional economies and facilitate their investments in those countries. The Government could continue to work hand in hand with private sector trade organisations such as the SMA and other Chambers to jointly carry out our regionalisation strategies.

    However, I wish to draw Members' attention to a problem confronting companies going offshore. An SMA survey showed that companies wanting to regionalise are facing great difficulties in recruiting Singapore managers to start up or run their operations in the region. Singapore is too comfortable for them to want to face the unfamiliar and often difficult working and living environment of the other countries. We should

Column: 289

inculcate in our managers and executives a sense of mission that by working abroad, they are helping to secure the future of Singapore. At the same time, we should provide incentives and remove obstacles to help them serve overseas successfully.

    While we must regionalise to add a second wing to our economy, we should continue to upgrade the mainstay of our economy which is our domestic economy. To meet increasing competition from the other developing economies of Asia, we must enhance our excellent capabilities such as our world-class infrastructure. Let me illustrate the importance of such a move with an incident.

    During Malaysian MITI Minister, Dato Seri Rafidah's visit, I took her for a ride, literally that is, to visit TECH Semiconductor's high technology plant in Woodlands. This $500 million plant is the latest wafer fabrication facility in this part of the world, for producing high density memory chips. After donning our clean-room garments which made us look like a spaceman, or a spacewoman in her case, we toured the fabrication area where we were told that the air was ultra clean in the Class 1 clean room. This means that there is less than one speck of sub-micron dust particle in one cubic foot of air. At the end of the tour, we sat down with TECH's President, Mr David Smith. Minister Rafidah came straight to the point by asking David, "Can Malaysia support such an operation like yours?" David replied, "I think you have all the necessary electrical power, water and other capabilities to meet our need for such a plant." But Minister Rafidah pressed on and asked, "What are the critical factors?" David paused and then replied, "Well, it is not just having the megawatts of electrical power or millions of litres of water that we need to keep this plant going 24 hours a day. We need completely reliable and uninterrupted supplies of such utilities because any stoppage will mean we have to scrap all our work in process and each time it can cost us losses amounting to millions of dollars. Singapore can meet this stringent requirement for efficient, reliable utilities."

Column: 290



    I agree with David Smith that such capability is what keeps Singapore competitive. Many newly developing economies are capable of putting in the required infrastructure, but quite often they are just trying to catch up with demand. Singapore excels in its ability to anticipate the future capability needs of the economy, and then plans meticulously to provide them ahead of demand. Once implemented, the projects are carried out efficiently and they continue to provide round the clock service to meet industries' exacting needs and demands for cost effective and highly reliable service. We should therefore spare no efforts to continue to upgrade and build world-class infrastructure and capabilities to remain internationally competitive so as to attract high technology and high value added industries to invest in Singapore.

    Talking about capabilities, I also strongly support the Government's plan to invest in the education and training of our people. This is the only way to move out of having to compete with countries which have abundant, low cost workers. However, we should address a nagging problem.

    More than 500,000 workers in Singapore have less than primary education and they are probably not aware of the serious competition they face from better educated workers in the region. They should be told that for every worker holding a job in Singapore, there are 720 workers in Asia waiting to take it away from him by willing to work harder for lower wages. For example, a worker in a garment manufacturing plant in Ho Chih Minh City is paid US$1 a day, compared to about US$25 a day for a Singapore worker. Yet, our group of more than half a million workers, most of them fairly matured in age, do not see the urgency, challenge or need to acquire more new skills to stay ahead.

    We need to help them understand the real magnitude of this problem and encourage them to acquire higher skills. In this respect, the Government should provide more incentives and remove any hindrances to encourage companies to set

Column: 291

up more work place training centres, like those found in Germany, for training skilled workers.

    In our efforts to regionalise our economies, companies venturing into the region often face a dilemma, "To pay or not to pay a bribe." Back home in Singapore, our system is squeaky clean and corruption is illegal and has been dealt with severely. I agree with the Senior Minister that a corruption free system is our competitive advantage and should be guarded at all cost. The problem facing our citizens and businessmen, however, is what they should do when an official in the foreign country asks for a bribe while carrying out his normal duty. Some call the bribe local practice, and give it such fanciful names as administration charges, processing fees, finder's fees and facilitation expenses. But such practice goes against the value system upheld so vigorously in Singapore.

    I asked some of my friends who head the regional operations of American MNCs in the region whether they succumbed to such pressure from corrupt officials. I was surprised to learn that most of them do not and some had never been asked to give a bribe. However, they told me that, if approached, they would often politely tell the officials that under their US companies' rules, no corruption was allowed, even in their foreign subsidiaries and it was also illegal under US laws to engage in corrupt practices. Apparently, because such a strong stand is prevalent amongst US corporations, the officials concerned do not waste time on them and leave them alone.

    However, sad to say, I also learnt that many companies coming from several other large developed countries do not have such rules and were either pro-actively or re-actively engaged in corruption of officials and politicians in many of their host countries. They therefore become fair game to the corrupt officials, so to speak.

    I think it is time we Singaporeans, whether as the Government, politicians, business leaders, businessmen or

Column: 292

ordinary citizens, should take a joint stand to say explicitly, "No corruption, please, we are Singaporeans." If such a stand is taken seriously and strictly adhered to by all Singaporeans and Singapore businessmen, whether travelling as tourists subject to harassment by customs or immigration officials at airports or businessmen being coerced to give bribes to facilitate the issue of a licence by officials, we will be sending a clear message to the officials of those countries that Singaporeans will not tolerate or participate in briberies. I admit that to take such a stand is easier said than done. But if US companies can do it, we should at least give it a try.

    On the other hand, in the meantime, no leaders, whether in Government or in the private sector, should publicly encourage or condone corruption by Singaporeans in other countries. Or else we will be subjecting our citizens and businessmen to aggravated harassment by officials looking for bribes. Such officials could say, "See, even your leaders think it is all right for you to bribe us." We should never compromise our integrity and moral principles by condoning briberies. We should condemn such practices so that one day, all Singaporeans, when challenged, could say without hesitation or fear, "No corruption, please, we are Singaporeans."

    This is a major challenge in our regionalisation efforts. I beseech all Singaporeans to stand up and meet this challenge without fear of any repercussions. I urge the Government to initiate and back such a move.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the motion and thank the President.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Thomson GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to support the motion proposed by Mr Loh Meng See, the Member for Kampong Glam GRC.

    The President, in his Opening Address, said that the Government will "focus on longer term policies to position ourselves for nation building". I fully agree that nation building should be the main attention of the Government. This is particularly important for Singapore where there is a need to bond together

Column: 293

people of diverse backgrounds, race and cultures. I believe that the work of nation building by the Government will have to be looked upon in two aspects: one is the material well-being of the people and the other is the spiritual or non-material well-being or social cohesion of the nation. These two aspects of material and spiritual welfare can be likened in modern day high-technology terms to the country's hardware and software. One cannot work without the other.

    The Government has put in a lot of energy to improve the hardware, or material well-being, of Singaporeans. This is reflected in the President's Speech which states that the Government's asset enhancement programme will enable every Singaporean to share the fruits of Singapore's success. Notably, the programmes to achieve this aim are the HDB Upgrading Programme and the HDB Interim Upgrading Programme. Another example is the recent move to get people to own shares of privatised companies, such as the Singapore Telecom.

    I believe that the material enhancement aspect has been very successful. This is demonstrated by the dramatic increase in the standard of living of Singaporeans over the last 15 to 20 years.

    In comparison to material well-being improvement, it appears that the effort to strengthen the spiritual well-being is less visible. Here, I use the term "spiritual well-being" to mean the non-material part of nation building. I do not mean spiritual in the sense of being religious. I am referring to the wider sense of social development and social cohesion, and to the emotional and mental sense of the people. I feel that better spiritual well-being of the nation can lead to our people becoming more cultivated, caring and sensitive. It serves to strengthen the emotional ties of the people to the country and the mutual bondage between the people.

    In contrast, material well-being or asset enhancement only serves as a reference, that is, to link the value of a citizen's personal wealth to the economic welfare of the country as a whole. Asset

Column: 294

enhancement serves to cause the people to be more aware of the material value to help to maintain the economic progress of the country. But it does not serve to increase the emotional bondage of the people to the nation and the mutual understanding between the people.

    Asset enhancement ties a person to the country by pulling at his purse string. Spiritual attachment of a person to his country tugs at his heartstrings. Obviously, it is stronger to bond a person to the country with two strings rather than one. Physical assets can be liquidated, but it is not easy to erase fond memories of a person for the country.

    As I have said earlier, there seems to be a stronger emphasis on material success. People tend to measure success based on monetary values. For example, car ownership is a display of wealth as indicated by the person's ability to pay for the high price of a car and the COE. Another example is that a person's success is very often measured by his earning power. As said by many Members in this House, the aspiration of the young is not so much as to become a Minister in the Government or a Minister in the Church, but to become a successful businessman with a big fat bank account. It is also stated by my colleague, Dr Wang Kai Yuen, that young people tend to give more regard to people with higher "street-smart quotient" or SQ. In his equation, people with higher SQ are people who are better at making money, and therefore earn more respect.

    I feel that it is important for the Government at this juncture to look into how to enhance the spiritual well-being or social cohesion of the people. We should look into how to weld our people together to have common goals, values and beliefs, and how to cultivate a more caring society with a higher sense of community spirit and togetherness, and how to attain a higher sense of appreciation of the arts. In simple language, we should move away from too much talk about "dollars and cents" and perhaps talk a little more about the "flowers and the trees."

Column: 295



    While our people are rushing to chase after the alluring smell of money, we should also stop and learn to smell the sweet fragrance of the flowers. To achieve this higher level of spiritual welfare among the people, attention should be paid to two particularly important institutions: first, the role of the education of the young and, second, the role of the mass media in influencing the thoughts of the adult population. Much can be said about these two aspects on how we can achieve the end results, but I shall leave the lengthy discourse to some other time.

    However, I would like to propose that, like the high-level Economic and Health Ministerial Committees that we have formed previously, it may be worthwhile to form a high level Community Development Ministerial Committee to look into our long term policies and measures to forge a national community spirit. Prominent personalities and the public may be invited to offer views and suggestions.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to move on to some other specific areas to comment on.

    First, ministerial and civil service salaries. All of us agree with the basic tenet that our Ministers and civil servants should be amply remunerated. There is a need to pay decent salaries so as to attract and retain good people both in the Government and in the civil service.

    I agree that it may be more expedient and politically more acceptable if a set formula can be arrived at to peg and automatically increase the salaries of Ministers and civil servants according to market conditions. It is natural to expect that as the country progresses, the people, including our Ministers and civil servants, should also be rewarded with higher salaries.
